item.title: The Root of Haiti’s Misery: Reparations to Enslavers
item.description: In 1791, enslaved Haitians ousted the French and founded a nation. But France made generations of Haitians pay for their freedom. How much it cost them was a mystery, until now.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter, Constant Méheut, Matt Apuzzo and Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: An illustration depicting plantations burning in 1791, during the Haitian Revolution.

item.title: ‘Such Bad Guys Will Come’: How One Russian Brigade Terrorized Bucha
item.description: A particularly fearsome unit of Moscow’s invading army arrived in the Kyiv suburb in mid-March. The soldiers’ reputation preceded them.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Daniel Berehulak

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Zelensky Says Military Aid Could Free Exports and Ease Food Prices
item.description: Ukraine’s president said wresting control of ports from Russia could help ease global price pressures from the war. President Biden signed one of the largest aid packages in decades on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen assisting comrades near the front line in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: How a French Bank Captured Haiti
item.description: It helped finance the Eiffel Tower as it drained millions from Haiti. The bank, C.I.C., won’t talk about it, but The Times tracked how much its investors made — and what Haiti lost.
item.dc:creator: Matt Apuzzo, Constant Méheut, Selam Gebrekidan and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Invade Haiti, Wall Street Urged. The U.S. Obliged.
item.description: The long occupation of Haiti began with a drumbeat from the bank that became Citigroup, decades of diplomatic correspondence and other records show.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan, Matt Apuzzo, Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: Aristide Demanded French Pay Reparations to Haiti. He Ended Up in Exile.
item.description: A firebrand Haitian president tried to hold France to account for its years of exploitation. He soon found himself ousted from power.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut, Catherine Porter, Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: How Much Haiti’s Freedom Cost: Takeaways From a Times Series
item.description: How did the modern world’s most successful slave revolt give birth to a desperately poor nation? Here is a summary of what a team of New York Times correspondents found out.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cannonballs at the Citadelle, largest military fortress in the Caribbean, stacked to defend against a feared French invasion.

item.title: ‘I Want to Reset My Brain’: Female Veterans Turn to Psychedelic Therapy
item.description: Traumatized by war and sexual assaults, some U.S. veterans and veterans’ spouses are seeking help in a Mexican clinic that treats depression and addiction with potent hallucinogens like toad poison.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Meridith Kohut
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women gathering in a circle during a psychedelic mushroom tea ceremony during a veterans therapy retreat at The Mission Within, in Tijuana, Mexico.

item.title: The Taliban Pressure Women in Afghanistan to Cover Up
item.description: The militant group in charge of the country is aggressively enforcing a decree requiring coverings from head to toe and crushing rare public protests against the order.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in Kabul, Afghanistan, in November.

item.title: Australia’s ‘Climate Election’ Finally Arrived. Will It Be Enough?
item.description: Voters rejected the deny-and-delay approach that has made Australia a global laggard on emission cuts. But how far the new government will go remains to be seen.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Anthony Albanese, Australia’s next prime minister, celebrating his victory on Saturday with his partner, Jodie Haydon, and his son, Nathan Albanese.

item.title: Rejecting ‘Love Letters’ to North Korea, Biden Offers Carrots and Sticks Instead
item.description: President Biden said he would consider expanding joint exercises with South Korea’s military that were scaled back during the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: South Korea’s new president, Yoon Suk-yeol, greeted President Biden on Saturday in Seoul.

item.title: 3 Tornadoes Strike Germany, Amid Heat Wave in Southern Europe
item.description: Extreme weather was also felt elsewhere in Europe as heat waves threatened Spain and parts of southern France.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A tornado raged through the city of Paderborn, Germany, on Friday.

item.title: Anthony Albanese to Become Australian Prime Minister
item.description: Like Biden before him, Anthony Albanese enters office more on the back of disgust at the conservative incumbent than enthusiasm for his leadership.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: The Labor leader, Anthony Albanese, with his partner, Jodie Haydon, and his son, Nathan, on election night in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: The Michigan Mink Mystery: How Did an Interspecies Outbreak Unfold?
item.description: The puzzling coronavirus cases highlight ongoing surveillance challenges and blind spots.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mink were collected for culling because of coronavirus fears on a farm in Naestved, Denmark, in November 2020.

item.title: 1897: Cambridge University Votes Against Degrees for Women
item.description: A resolution to grant degrees to women was rejected by a large majority and men celebrated the result with fireworks.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: As Biden Signs $40 Billion Aid Package for Ukraine, Calls Grow for a Cease-Fire
item.description: But a diplomatic resolution to the war still looks remote, amid searing questions about what would constitute a “victory” for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Andrew E. Kramer and Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers working at a charity outside of Lviv, Ukraine, on Friday. The war has now lasted three months, and an outcome in the conflict is unclear.

item.title: The Russian Orthodox Leader at the Core of Putin’s Ambitions
item.description: Patriarch Kirill I has provided spiritual cover for the invasion of Ukraine, reaping vast resources for his church in return. Now, in an extraordinary step, the E.U. is threatening him with sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

item.title: ‘A form of hope’: As air-raid sirens sound, a Lviv orchestra opens a summer festival with Mozart’s Requiem.
item.description: Even as the Lviv Philharmonic theater became a wartime hub for humanitarian supplies, it has remained a home for musicians and choirs.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: At Davos, a Referendum on the World Economic Forum
item.description: Many values espoused by the World Economic Forum — globalization, liberalism, free market capitalism, representative democracy — are under attack.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:description: The last time the World Economic Forum held its annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland — in January 2020, before the pandemic — protesters turned out to challenge its message of globalization.

item.title: A lead for the Labor opposition, but it’s unclear whether it will reach an outright majority.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Damien Cave
item.media:description: Outside a polling station in Sydney on Saturday.

item.title: Russian Forces Are Attempting Another Crossing of the Seversky Donets River, Ukraine Says
item.description: The 650-mile-long Seversky Donets River originates in Russia and meanders southeast through the Donbas region before re-entering Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: Fun, but With Structure
item.description: When socializing is stressful, rule-bound role-playing games can offer some relief.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: For Elite? Yes. Ostentatious? Yes. But Also Effective.
item.description: For all the criticism of the World Economic Forum’s display of wealth, productive partnerships are indeed formed at Davos, participants say.
item.dc:creator: David Kaufman
item.media:description: Participants gathered in the Congress Centre during the World Economic Forum in January 2020, the last time the event was held in person before the global pandemic struck in full force.

item.title: Royal Visit to Canada Rife With Symbolism, But Little Substance
item.description: The often hectic royal tours, like this week’s by Prince Charles and Camilla, his wife, are short on substance if long on symbolism.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.media:description: The end of the three-day visit to Canada by Prince Charles and Camilla, his wife, to mark Queen Elizabeth’s 70 years on the throne.

item.title: Why Australians Must Vote on Election Day
item.description: Compulsory voting is seen as forcing candidates toward the political center.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: A line in Melbourne on Tuesday for early voting.

item.title: Australian Democracy Comes With a Side of Grilled Onions
item.description: In a beloved tradition, every Election Day sausages are sold near polling stations as fund-raisers for local schools, churches and community groups.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: A barbecue stand serving “democracy sausages” outside a polling station in Melbourne in 2019.

item.title: Australia decides whether to extend conservatives’ reign.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave

item.title: Anthony Albanese Pitches ‘Safe Change” in Australian Election
item.description: The opposition leader has emphasized the good that effective government can do.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Anthony Albanese on Saturday with his partner, Jodie Haydon, left, and his dog. He has sought to assure voters that he is a centrist.

item.title: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison Urges Voters to Opt for What They Know
item.description: His tenure hasn’t always been smooth, with moments that have tested the Australian public’s faith in his leadership
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison after casting his vote in Sydney on Saturday.

item.title: France’s New Cabinet Mixes Fresh and Familiar, Hinting at Macron’s Priorities
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron’s newly announced government combines continuity with change, as first-term veterans were joined by newcomers in top positions at the foreign and education ministries.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The outgoing French education minister, Jean-Michel Blanquer, center, shaking hands with his successor, Pap Ndiaye, on Friday.

item.title: Russia Hustles to Recruit Soldiers and Halts Gas Supplies to Finland
item.description: The war has evolved into something of a stalemate that has seriously depleted Russia’s conventional war capabilities, even as it has made some gains.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Russian-backed soldier standing guard over a bus carrying Ukrainian soldiers who surrendered from the Azovstal plant in Mariupol on Friday.

item.title: The Ransom: A Look Under the Hood
item.description: Thousands of pages of original documents, and hundreds of books and articles. Here are the historians and researchers on which the Haiti project drew.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter, Constant Méheut, Selam Gebrekidan and Matt Apuzzo
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times

item.title: A Guide to Australia’s Election
item.description: Election Day has arrived. Here’s what to watch.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Anthony Albanese, the leader of the opposition, during a talk with undecided voters last month. He has toned down Labor’s positions on traditional hot-button issues like taxes.

item.title: U.S. Company Supplying Russian Military Seeks Exit, Caught Between Sanctions and Kremlin
item.description: Arconic runs a huge Russian metal plant, bought in an era of cooperation between the U.S. and Russia. Now it is struggling, after years of increasing Russian military aggression.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: The Alcoa and Arconic headquarters in Pittsburgh in January. Arconic is a Fortune 500 company that is one of America’s largest metalworking firms.

item.title: Chaos in Israel Gives New Chance to Old Face: Benjamin Netanyahu
item.description: Mr. Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, lost office last summer. Now the coalition that replaced him is crumbling — potentially leading to new elections that could return him to power.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the former Prime Minister of Israel, speaking in Jerusalem last month. A vote for new elections could pave the way for his return to power.

item.title: Australia’s Election: What to Watch and What’s at Stake
item.description: While voters are most focused on cost-of-living issues, the opposition Labor Party has made the election a referendum on the conduct of Prime Minister Scott Morrison.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Asanka Brendon Ratnayake for The New York Times
item.media:description: Commuters in Melbourne last month. Australians go to the polls on Saturday to choose a government.

item.title: How Russia Uses Show Trials to Punish Putin’s Enemies
item.description: Moscow may label the Azov fighters who defended the Mariupol steel plant as terrorists — raising the prospect of a high-profile trial. The Kremlin has a long tradition of using the courts for political goals.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A bus carrying members of the Ukrainian armed forces, who surrendered to Russian forces at the besieged Azovstal steel mill.

item.title: BBC Allowed to Publish Accusations of Abuse Against MI5 Agent
item.description: The news organization found that evidence suggested an agent for the domestic intelligence agency had a history of right-wing extremism and was abusive toward women, but it wasn’t allowed to fully identify him.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The headquarters of MI5, Britain’s domestic security intelligence agency, in London in 2015.

item.title: Washington Warns Britain to Temper Its Spat With E.U. Over Northern Ireland
item.description: A senior U.S. diplomat urged London and Brussels to discreetly resolve their disputes, citing the need to unify the West behind Ukraine amid Russia’s onslaught.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A so-called peace wall separating Catholic and Protestant neighborhoods in Belfast.

item.title: What Is Monkeypox?
item.description: There have been dozens of cases reported in recent weeks among populations not typically vulnerable to the disease.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: European Center for Disease Prevention and Control
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Francesco Vaia, the director of a hospital in Rome where three cases of monkeypox have been confirmed and isolated, conducts a news conference on Friday.

item.title: In South Korea, Joe Biden Seeks to Rebuild Economic Ties Across Asia
item.description: The president plans to unveil a new regional economic framework, but some in the region wonder whether it will be an empty exercise.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden and President Yoon Suk-yeol of South Korea, second right, visited the Samsung semiconductor Pyeongtaek Campus in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: U.N. Human Rights Chief to Make First Trip to China Since 2005
item.description: Rights groups say Michelle Bachelet’s trip, including a visit to the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, where Beijing has cracked down on the Uyghur minority, will be a test of her office’s credibility.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Michelle Bachelet, pictured in Geneva, Switzerland, in 2020, will be the first U.N. human rights chief to visit China since 2005.

item.title: Free Ambulances in Mogadishu, Thanks to Aamin Ambulance
item.description: Dismayed that victims of the incessant violence in Somalia’s capital were being rolled to hospitals on wooden carts and in wheelbarrows, a dentist decided to do something about it.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Abdulkadir Abdirahman Adan, the founder of Aamin Ambulance, the only free emergency transport system in Mogadishu, Somalia.

item.title: G7 Nations Pledge $20 Billion to Ukraine
item.description: Financing will be directed to keep government operations running amid the Russian war.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
item.media:description: Some of the Group of 7 leaders during a NATO summit in Brussels in March. Finance ministers from these countries also discussed ways to keep pressure on Russia while minimizing the blowback to their own economies.

item.title: In Pictures: Sri Lanka’s Protesters Remain Defiant
item.description: As the pain of an economic crisis deepens, a nation’s anger and desperation are visible.
item.dc:creator: Atul Loke and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Protesters encountered water cannons and tear gas on Thursday in Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka.

item.title: A New Kind of Drug
item.description: How the country’s drug problem is changing, and why it’s growing.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elizabeth Cheryl Dillender and her daughter, Kristin. Their relative died of a fentanyl overdose last year.

item.title: As China Doubles Down on Lockdowns, Some Chinese Seek an Exit
item.description: Inquiries to immigration consultants have surged; social media users trade tips on how to get abroad. But the government aims to “strictly restrict nonessential exit activities.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: At Pudong International Airport in Shanghai last year. There are signs that China will continue to discourage overseas travel even once pandemic rules are relaxed.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Hungary’s thirst for Russian oil.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Hungarian oil refinery.

item.title: Officials Report a Possible Monkeypox Case in New York
item.description: The patient is under care at Bellevue Hospital while further testing is conducted.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: Russell Regnery/Cdc Cynthia S. Goldsmith/Via Reuters
item.media:description: An electron microscopic image shows mature, oval-shaped monkeypox virus particles.

item.title: Russian Rock Singer Charged After Condemning the Ukraine War
item.description: The singer made the comments less than three months after Russia enacted a law that would punish spreading “false information” about its invasion.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuri Shevchuk, lead singer of the Russian band DDT, in the band’s recording studio in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 2010.

item.title: Prince Charles Dances With Indigenous People to End Canada Visit
item.description: On the prince’s third and final day in Canada, he said he was “deeply moved’’ by the stories of those who survived brutal treatment in residential schools.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.media:description: A traditional drum demonstration was held for Prince Charles during a visit with the Dettah Community of the Yellowknives Dene First Nation on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Surpasses 1 Million Known Covid Deaths
item.description: While Covid stole lives from all strata of society, it magnified disparities based on factors like sex, age, health care access, income and housing.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial to lives lost during the Covid-19 pandemic at the Baker Street Jewish Cemeteries in Boston in September.

item.title: Moscow Moves to Russify Seized Ukraine Land, Signaling Annexation
item.description: The territory occupied by Russian forces so far in the three-month-old invasion deserves “a worthy place in our Russian family,” a Kremlin official who toured the region said.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: A Russian military vehicle in Mariupol, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Begins Trip to Asia Meant to Reassure Allies of Focus on China
item.description: With the administration’s attention having shifted to Ukraine, President Biden plans to emphasize that the United States can counter aggression in both Europe and Asia.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden departing for South Korea on Thursday. Mr. Biden’s first trip to Asia will pose diplomatic challenges on several fronts.

item.title: Biden Seeks Swift Effort to Bring Finland and Sweden Into NATO
item.description: Speedy approval seems likely among most members of the alliance in the wake of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but Turkey’s objections remain a sticking point.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times

item.title: Ukrainian Oligarch Mulls Selling Superyacht to Distance Himself From Russia
item.description: The richest man in Ukraine has committed to building back his country. But he is also constructing a luxury ship that would rival a yacht that the U.S. government believes may belong to Vladimir Putin.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe

item.title: Russian Gymnast Who Wore Pro-War ‘Z’ Symbol on Podium Is Given One-Year Ban
item.description: The gymnast, Ivan Kuliak, wore the symbol while standing at the podium next to the Ukrainian gold medalist.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia Seeks More Control Over Occupied Ukraine
item.description: Plus the war is causing hunger in Africa and the “teals” are looking to upend Australia’s elections.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homes destroyed by bombardment in the village of Vilkhivka on Thursday.
